Brooksby,
To Sask. November 1906.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE
No. 2
PIONEER EXPERIENCE: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; there may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Don't hesitate to give details of descriptive particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1921, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this Province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Pioneer Questionnaires:

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires:

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the Permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Inkover, Saskatoon, Sask.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name: Christopher Ormond Atkins
2. Your address: Brookby, Sask.
3. Date: May 12, 1902
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Canada - The Province - England
5. What was your father's name and occupation?: Burgess Special Offerings - Flour mills (water-powered)
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): November 1906
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible:
   - St. Mary's, 1898-1906
   - Toronto, 1898-1906
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question, if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child")
9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My family came - my parents (my) cousins. That in times of opportunity would I enter mills was about perfect and I particularly considered that we - my brother, sisters, myself - would be closer to Canada.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)

My father came from Texas through Willard's Court. He knew of the district. He came to the area. He had heard from a clerk in a store - so a man repairing the sidewalks. He had been up in this country.
Atkings, Christopher Ormond
Brookby,
To Sask., November 1906.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES, REGINA, SK

No. 2

PIONEER EXAMINATION: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

1. Your full name:
Christopher Ormond Atkings

2. Your address:
Brookby

3. Date:
November 21, 1906

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
Ontario - Ontario - England

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
Robert Daniel Atkings - Flour miller (locates-woodenly)

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
November - 1906

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates whenever possible.
Arrived in Toronto, May 1898. From England.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you are under 18 years of age.)
I was 18 years old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
My parents came - I came along too.

my father's friend (So) carried. That he knew of operating wood flour mills was about picked out & probably consulted that we - (my brother's family) tried - to go there in Canada.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or Government Information?)
my father read in newspapers. Through railroad agent.

After hearing of the district, & etc...

the government had found them unsuitable & family decided to come west! We heard from a clerk in a store - so mean repaying the sidewalks. But we'd turn up in this country.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? (i.e., they thought we were going to be too far from civilization, but we thought it was a chance to get away from the city.)

12. Did you travel by train or with a party (family, friends, or other group)?

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train from Regina to Calgary in the fall of 1914.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

The railway failed to place our car so that the whole world be carried very nearly all in on arrival at Star City (14-5 days).

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Of day or so in Star City. (That's one year old - one night at one)

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

On SE 22-47, 16w12m-16b10l0k10f15.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Saskatoon - for the summer of 1914

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Mill in my father's orchard plant - we had a small dairy - 3 cows, select dairy Kinged Heifers - after leaving school (Grade 7) I worked on four ranching for Blue Ribbon Co. about one year campaigning.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your destination to come to Western Canada (in English) thought we were going to be far from anything good.

12. Did you travel by train or with a party (family, friends or other groups).

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train from Regina to Prince Albert in the fall. We came back by train.

14. What incidents of the journey that do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitements etc.)

The railway helped to place our car so that the car could be carried anywhere all in one arrival after 60 miles (or 5 days)

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Of days or 38 in St. Albert (not sure how old) - one night at mine

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Homesteaded - 22-47, 16w23m - 16 mile North of Saskatoon

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

Saskatoon - for the summer of 1914

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Mill in M.P. Plant - my father worked there at the city mill. We had a small dairy. We also kept a few cows. We lived in a Blue Ribbon house.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Salt Lake because of your marriage? (If so, who?)

23. In case any particular experience of pioneer days stands out in your memory which you would like to record:

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How did you travel? By what means of travel?

NO - For Guardian people over a year in age, a muffle, a foot race, no school.

Yes - For many years, hard work mostly, walked only a few times with rain, (rain was hard on our knees) walked only a few times not loaded heavy (we used to borrow a lot) whenever we need known open to travel, an axe shovel, a chain, a little money, an extra suit of clothes.

Ken was taken away quick after new thank had to be cut around skylight, or bad mind little had to be fed with bread.

33. How did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

34. Then did you have a telephone and was company provided?

35. How did you make your decision to move to Saskatchewan?
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes - Some were misfits - couldn't stand pioneering - some found it too lonely - Some young fellows found nothing but hard labor - There were some who just took up land so as to have a place to hang out, while hunting, trapping or making lime kilns - Some lost out to mining companies etc.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Some - it seemed to weed out those who were not so successful as others - very few, if any came back -

If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

For several years I was a municipal road inspector.

If you or any of your family or friends say you "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here having dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change.

Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3), (4).

Brookdale - named by railroad officials - after support near the bank - c. 1921.

Willow Creek Municipality (458) - after creek, so named running through district.

Willow Valley School - after early settlers, after surrounding country.

Eden Bridge P.O. named after Eden Bridge Kent, Eng. - suggested by a man from Kent River who was present when name was first considered. NOT as the Jewish Colonyists say "because it seemed like the Gardens of Eden." The bridge across the Carrot River here, was put in by British forces when the Jews and followers - 1908.

Eden Bridge School - after Eden Bridge P.O.

Anderson School - after Gen. Anderson - 1918.

Sandhill Creek - by early settlers, after description of district. 1907

Ridge Dale - named by Mr. Jack Grant about 1905. The original P.O. was some two miles SW of present town. Description.

Star City - supposed to be named after Walter Starkey, who objected to his name.
Maryville School (6-8 west of here) named by ratepayers after Mary Piper, daughter of pioneer settler.

Campbellville School (4-5 mile NW star bit) named by ratepayers after early settler.

Irvington School named after Mr. Irving.

Gravenhurst, Ontario - pioneers

Poveshull, Ontario - pioneer farmers

Ratner - P.O. (E29748)

16 W 2 M. named after early settler.

State # P.O. in Township

Gronlid - after Rev. Gronlid

Lutheran minister

Fort River P.O. named by early settlers who used to disfigure the ground.

Bridge across the Cass River was built in 1908.

Bridge School - after Selahhide P.O.

Henderson - Se. 1/4 Sec. Henderson - 1918.

Sanctuary Church - erected so late, the church building was completed in 1905. The original being used.

Poveshull - named by Mrs. J. J. Powell, known as Mrs. Powell.

Ridgefield - named by Mrs. J. J. Powell, known as Mrs. Powell.

Stan Colly - extended to be named after Mr. Stanbury, who figured in the history.
